key_issues: Here are the extracted main legal issues:
Abandonment of opposition under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017.
Deemed abandonment of opposition due to non-action within specified time limit.
Proper service of counter statement and documents to the applicant/Appellant.
Time extension for filing evidence in support of opposition under Rule 50 (1)(i) of the Trade Marks Rules 2002.
Application of Tribunal Reforms Act 2021 on IPAB appeals.
Jurisdictional implications of transfer of appeal from learned IPAB to Delhi High Court.
Interpretation of Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017 regarding deemed abandonment of opposition.
Applicability of Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act for appealing against deemed abandonment of opposition.
Whether non-action within specified time limit for filing evidence constitutes waiver of right to oppose trade mark application.
metadata.decision_summary:
Here is a comprehensive summary of the case:

**Background**

This case involves a dispute over the registration of a device mark under the Trade Marks Act 1999. Mahesh Gupta (Appellant) opposed an application filed by Vinayak Healthcare Limited (Respondent 2), seeking to register the device mark in respect of non-alcoholic drinks and beverages, including aerated water, beer, and porter.

**Legal Issues**

The main legal issue is whether the Appellant's opposition was deemed abandoned as per Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017 (2017 Rules), and whether the Deputy Registrar's order dated August 7, 2019, holding the opposition to be abandoned was correct.

**Arguments**

The Appellant submitted that it had filed evidence in support of its opposition on June 10, 2010, albeit after a delay of four months. The Appellant sought an extension of time and acknowledged the delayed filing. However, the Deputy Registrar held the opposition to be deemed abandoned under Rule 45(2) of the 2017 Rules.

**Court Findings**

The High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (Division Bench) considered the appeal filed by the Appellant under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act 1999 against the order of the Deputy Registrar. The court noted that all proceedings before the Deputy Registrar took place when the Trade Marks Rules 2002 (2002 Rules) were in force, and not the 2017 Rules.

**Legal Issues Raised**

The court identified several legal issues:

1. Whether the Deputy Registrar was correct in applying Rule 45(2) of the 2017 Rules to hold the opposition abandoned.
2. Whether the Appellant's delay in filing evidence should have been considered under Rule 45 (deemed abandonment) of the 2002 Rules or the 2017 Rules.

**Court Decision**

The court held that the Depute Registrar erred in law by passing the order under the 2017 Rules, as all proceedings took place when the 2002 Rules were in force. The court noted that Rule 45 (deemed abandonment) of the 2017 Rules was not applicable to this case.

**Decision**

The court allowed the Appellant's appeal and set aside the order passed by the Deputy Registrar holding the opposition to be abandoned. However, no order has been passed on the merits of the application or opposition at this stage.

Note: This summary is based on a limited understanding of trademarks laws in India. For an authoritative account of trademark law and practice, experts should consult relevant sources from the Indian Trade Marks Act 1999 and Rules related to the case cited above.

the 2017 Rules cannot, therefore, prejudice the applicability of the

9. 
The dispute has, therefore, to be examined in the light of Rule 
50(1) of the 2002 Rules. What has to be seen, therefore, is whether the 
opposition of the appellant could be treated as having deemed to have 
been abandoned by applying Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules.    
 
10. 
A coordinate Single Bench of this Court of Hon’ble Mr. Justice 
Budar Durrez Ahmed, as he then was, has examined this aspect in 
detail in Sunrider Corporation, U.S.A. v. Hindustan Lever Ltd4. The 
relevant passages from the said decision may be reproduced thus: 
 
―8. 
Reading Rule 50, it is clear that the evidence by way of 
affidavit in support of an opposition to the registration of a trade 
mark has to be filed within two months of the service of a copy of 
the counter-statement on the opponent. This period of two months 
is further extendable by a period of one month in the aggregate 
thereafter as the Registrar may on request allow. Clearly, in the 
first instance, the evidence affidavit has to be filed within two 
months of the receipt of a copy of the counter-statement. The 
Registrar may extend this period by a further one month in the 
aggregate if a request for the same is made in time. Sub-rule (2) of 
Rule 50 makes it clear that if an opponent takes no action under 
Sub-rule (1) within the time mentioned therein, he shall be deemed 
to have abandoned his opposition. It is also interesting to note that 
Sub-rule (3) refers to the application for extension of the period of 
one month mentioned in Sub-rule (1). It is also stipulated that such 
an application has to be made in Form TM-56 accompanied by the 
prescribed fee before the expiry of the period of two months 
mentioned therein. So, it is clear that a strict regimen has been 
prescribed for the filing of evidence by way of affidavit in support 
of an opposition. A plain reading of the provisions makes it 
abundantly clear that the evidence has to be filed within two

months in the first instance and, if an appropriate application for 
extension of time is made before the expiry of the period of two 
months and if such application is allowed by the Registrar, then 
latest by a further month. In other words, under no circumstances 
can the evidence affidavit be filed beyond the maximum three 
months prescribed under the said rule. In case the opponent has 
not taken steps within the prescribed time, then there is no option 
left with the Registrar but to deem that the opponent has 
abandoned his opposition.‖ 
(Emphasis Supplied) 
 
11. 
Ms. Rajeshwari seeks, however, to distinguish the decision in 
Sunrider4 essentially on two grounds.   She relies, in the first instance, 
on the judgment of a learned Single Judge of the High Court of 
Gujarat in Wyeth Holdings Corpn. v. Controller General of Patents, 
Designs and Trade Marks5 , which holds, in paras 58 to 60 thus: 
―58.  
In view of the nature of the prayer sought for, there is no 
question of any alternative remedy being available to the 
petitioners. Having found the submissions made by the learned 
senior counsel appearing for the petitioners with substance, the 
same are accepted. There is no question of the petition being  
dismissed on the ground of alternative remedy being available. 
59.  
In view of the aforesaid discussion, in view of the settled 
legal position that subordinate legislation cannot travel beyond the 
scope of main legislation and having regard to the provisions 
of Section 131 which provides for extension of time, this Court has 
only two options, either to declare Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 as ultra 
virus the Act or by employing principle of 'harmonious 
construction', to read Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 to be a 'directory' one. 
60. 
In the considered opinion of this Court, there is no reason 
much less a compelling reason for which the first option should be 
exercised and the 'Rule' be struck down by holding it to be 
'mandatory'. As against that, it is a well settled position of law that 
principle of 'harmonious construction' should be pressed into 
service and Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 be read as 'directory'. This 
Court is of the opinion that by declaring Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50, 
'directory', no injustice or prejudice is going to be caused to any 
party. On the contrary, it will be serving the interest of justice. 
Hence, second option is exercised. Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 is held 
to be 'directory' in nature.‖ 
 
                                          
5 2006 SCC OnLine Guj 620

Wyeth5, she submits, was not noticed in Sunrider4.  
 
13. 
With greatest respect, I am unable to subscribe to the view 
expressed by the High Court of Gujarat in Wyeth5. 
 
14. 
To my mind, the view espoused in para 60 of the decision in 
Wyeth5, if accepted, would amount to no less than re-writing of the 
applicable statutory provisions. Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules is even 
more peremptory, in its application, than Rule 48 of the succeeding 
2017 Rules. While providing a period of two months to an opponent 
opposing an application seeking registration of a trade mark file its 
evidence after receipt of the counter-statement of the applicant, Rule 
50(1) empowers the Registrar to extend the said period only upto one 
month, specifically using the words ―not exceeding one month‖. The 
words ―not exceeding one month‖ are mandatory in their import.  The 
learned Registrar could not, therefore, grant extension of more than 
one month beyond the period of two months from the date of service, 
on the opponent opposing the registration of a mark, of a copy of the 
counter statement.  Grant of any further extension would clearly be in 
the teeth of Rule 50(1). 
 
15. 
Rule 50(2) is even clearer in its import.  It states, in 
unambiguous terms, that, if the opponent took no action under Rule 
50(1) within the time period mentioned therein – meaning two months 
extendable by a maximum period of one month – he shall be deemed 
to have abandoned his opposition.  
 
16. 
Deemed abandonment of the opposition, therefore, follows as 
an inexorable statutory sequitur to the failure, on the part of the

opponent, in filing the evidence in support of the opposition within the 
period envisaged in Rule 50(1).  Deemed abandonment, therefore, 
occurs by operation of the statute. Even sans any judicial or quasi-
judicial order, therefore, if the opponent opposing the application 
seeking grant of the trade mark fails to file its evidence in support of 
the opposition within a maximum of three months from the receipt, by 
it, of the counter-statement of the trade mark applicant, the opposition 
would ipso facto be deemed to be abandoned irrespective of whether 
any order to that effect is, or is not, passed by any judicial or quasi-
judicial forum. 
 
17. 
The view expressed in Wyeth5, if accepted, would amount to 
rendering largely otiose Rule 50(2) of the 2002 Rules. With respect, 
therefore, it is not possible to accept the said view.  
 
18. 
Ms. Rajeshwari also sought to place reliance on Rule 1056 of 
the 2002 Rules read with Section 1317 of the 1999 Act. 
 
19. 
Though these provisions have been considered by the 
coordinate Bench in Sunrider4, Ms. Rajeshwari advances a 
submission which, according to her, was not advanced in Sunrider4 
and was not, therefore, considered.  She draws attention to the 
                                          
6 105. 
Extension of time.— 
(1) An application for extension of time under Section 131 (not being 
a time expressly provided in the Act or prescribed by Rule 79 or by sub-rule (4) of Rule 80 or a time for the 
extension of which provision is made in the rules) shall be made in Form TM-56. 
(2) Upon an application made under sub-rule (1) the Registrar, if satisfied that the circumstances are such as 
to justify the extension of the time applied for, may, subject to the provisions of the rules where a maximum 
time limit is prescribed and subject to such conditions as he may think fit to impose, extend the time and 
notify the parties accordingly and the extension may be granted though the time for doing the act or taking the 
proceeding for which it is applied for has already expired. 
7131.  
Extension of time.— 
(1) If the Registrar is satisfied, on application made to him in the 
prescribed manner and accompanied by the prescribed fee, that there is sufficient cause for extending the time 
for doing any act (not being a time expressly provided in this Act), whether the time so specified has expired 
or not, he may, subject to such conditions as he may think fit to impose, extend the time and inform the 
parties accordingly. 
(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall be deemed to require the Registrar to hear the parties before disposing of 
an application for extension of time, and no appeal shall lie from any order of the Registrar under this section.

--- PAGE 8 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/001627 
C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022 
 
Page 8 of 9    
 
parenthesized words in Rule 105(1) reading ―not being a time 
expressly provided in the Act or prescribed by rule 79 or by sub-rule 
(4) of rule 80 or a time for the extension of which provision is made in 
the rules‖. According to Ms. Rajeshwari, the import of the afore-
extracted parenthesized words in Rule 105(1) was to restrict the 
inflexibility of the provision only to cases where the time was 
provided in the Act or prescribed by Rule 79 or Rule 80(4).   
 
20. 
The submission is obviously unacceptable, as the parentheses 
also include the words ―or a time for the extension of which provision 
is made in the rules‖. As already noted, Rule 50(1) provides for 
extension of time and curtails the maximum period by which such 
extension could be granted to one month.  The provision for extension 
of time as contained in Rule 50(1), therefore, rules out the 
applicability of Rule 105 to the facts of the present case.  
 
21. 
On all other aspects, the coordinate Bench in Sunrider4, having 
examined the issue in law in detail, this Bench does not deem it 
necessary to reinvent the wheel. I express my respectful concurrence 
with the views expressed in the passages from Sunrider4 extracted 
hereinabove which, unfortunately for the appellant, cover the case 
against it on all fours.  
 
22. 
I see no reason, therefore, to differ with the ultimate decision, of 
the Deputy Registrar, to deem the opposition of the appellant as 
having been abandoned.  The deemed abandonment would, however, 
be under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules, and not Rule 45(1) of the 2017 
Rules.  
 
Digitally Signed By:SUNIL
SINGH NEGI
Signing Date:04.03.2023
16:11:50
Signature Not Verified

C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022

23. 
Subject to that modification, the impugned order dated 7th 
August 2019 is, therefore, upheld.  
 
24. 
The appeal is dismissed.

**PDF Source:** "Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks" (2023/DHC/001627)

The appeal is against an order dated August 7, 2019, by the Deputy Registrar of Trade Marks, where the opposition filed by the appellant was deemed to have been abandoned under Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017.

**Key Facts and Proceedings:**

* The application for extension of time in filing evidence was made on June 11, 2010.
* The Deputy Registrar held the opposition to be abandoned due to failure to file evidence within the stipulated timeframe.
* The appellant filed an appeal under Section 91 of the Trade Marks Act before the Intellectual Property Appellate Board (IPAB), which was transferred to the High Court of Delhi after the abolition of IPAB.

**Legal Argument:**

* The issue revolves around the application of Rule 45(2) of the Trade Marks Rules 2017 and whether the opposition can be deemed abandoned due to delayed filing of evidence.

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
Here's a summary of the given document section:

**Case Overview**

The case is Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr (2023/DHC/001627). The High Court of Delhi is hearing an appeal against the rejection of the appellant's opposition to the registration of a trade mark, on grounds that their objection was considered abandoned.

**Background and Facts**

Mahesh Gupta (Appellant) filed an opposition against Registrar of Trade Marks (Respondent) under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules. The application for trade mark registration, counter-statement, and evidence were all filed before the 2017 Rules came into force. Respondent 2 applied for the registration.

**Decision**

The Court found that the Deputy Registrar erred in law by passing an impugned order under the 2017 Rules when proceedings took place under the 2002 Rules. The repeal of the 2002 Rules (without prejudice to anything done before) cannot affect the applicability of the 2002 Rules regarding evidence filed under Rule 50(1). 

**Argument and Ruling**

The dispute should be examined under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules, which stipulates that if the opponent does not take action within two months + one month extension (allowed by the Registrar), their opposition will be deemed abandoned. The Court concluded that this rule applies to the present case.

**Judgment**

The matter should be re-examined in light of Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules, considering whether the opposition was deemed abandoned due to non-action within specified timelines.

Source: [32. Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf](https://www.pmf.org.in/index.php/eCourts/Case-Law-Service)

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
Here is a summary of the provided legal document section in 300 words or less:

**Case Details**

* Case Name: Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001627
* C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022

**Context**

The case is an appeal against the decision of the Registrar of Trade Marks, which deemed an opponent's opposition as abandoned due to non-compliance with Rule 50(1) of the Trade Marks Rules, 2002.

**Legal Arguments**

* The applicant's advocate, Ms. Rajeshwari, relies on a High Court of Gujarat judgment (Wyeth Holdings Corpn. v. Controller General of Patents, Designs and Trade Marks) to argue that Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 is directory in nature.
* However, the Delhi High Court declines to accept this view, holding that it would amount to rewriting the applicable statutory provisions.
* The court notes that Rule 50(1) empowers the Registrar to extend the period only up to one month beyond the initial period of two months, and granting further extensions would be in direct contravention of the rule.

**Decision**

The Delhi High Court declines to exercise the second option of declaring Sub-rule (2) of Rule 50 as "directory" in nature. Instead, it sticks to the view that subordinate legislation cannot travel beyond the scope of main legislation, and therefore Sub-rule (2) can be declared ultra vires the Act.

**PDF Source**

**Summary of Page 7 from PDF: 32. Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks**

This page discusses the interpretation of Rule 50(1) of the Trademark Rules, 2002, which deals with the time limit for filing evidence in support of opposition.

* The court holds that deemed abandonment occurs automatically if the opponent fails to file its evidence within a maximum of three months from receipt of the counter-statement.
* This view is taken to avoid rendering Rule 50(2) otiose (meaning, having no practical effect), as suggested by the opposing party in Wyeth.
* The court then considers Rule 105 of the 2002 Rules and Section 131(7) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

**Key points:**

* Deemed abandonment occurs automatically if evidence is not filed within three months from counter-statement receipt.
* Rule 50(2) would become otiose if the opposing view in Wyeth were accepted.

tree_structure.summary:
The document is a court decision from Case No. C.A.(COMM.IPD-TM) 143/2022, Mahesh Gupta vs Registrar of Trade Marks & Anr., Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/001627.

**Background:** Mahesh Gupta filed an appeal against the order of the Deputy Registrar dated August 7, 2019, deeming his opposition to be abandoned in a trade mark case.

**Arguments:** Ms. Rajeshwari, Counsel for Appellant Mahesh Gupta, argued that the provision for deemed abandonment under Rule 105(1) was restricted to cases where time was provided in the Act or prescribed by rule (79 or 80(4)). However, this argument was rejected as the words "or a time for the extension of which provision is made in the rules" included Rule 50(1), which provides for an extension of time.

**Decisions:**

* The court agreed with the views expressed in Sunrider (a coordinate Bench decision) on all aspects.
* The Deputy Registrar's order deeming the opposition abandoned was upheld, subject to a modification that it was under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules, not Rule 45(1) of the 2017 Rules.
* The appeal was dismissed.

**Key Dates:**

* August 7, 2019: Deputy Registrar's order deeming opposition abandoned
* March 2, 2023: Court's decision upholding the impugned order

**Note:** This summary is based on the PDF document "Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks.pdf".

nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 8 from the provided PDF (Mahesh Gupta v. Registrar of Trade Marks):

The court examines the implication of "parenthesized words" in Rule 105(1) of the trade mark rules. Ms. Rajeshwari argues that these words restrict inflexibility to cases where time is provided in the Act or prescribed by Rule 79 or Rule 80(4). The court finds this submission unacceptable as the parentheses also include "or a time for the extension of which provision is made in the rules", which refers to Rule 50(1) that provides for the extension of time.

The court notes that the provision for extension of time in Rule 50(1) curtails the maximum period by which such extension could be granted to one month. This rules out the applicability of Rule 105 to the case. The court also cites a previous decision (Sunrider) on the same issue, expressing respect and concurrence with its views.

The ultimate decision in this case is based on the deemed abandonment of the opposition under Rule 50(1) of the 2002 Rules, not Rule 45(1) of the 2017 Rules.
